title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006". It establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, encompassing approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description to Congress, with corrections allowed for clerical errors. The map will be available for public inspection in the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service. The Secretary may correct errors in the map and description, which will be available for public inspection. The management of the scenic area aims to protect its quality, water resources, natural characteristics, and vegetation. The Secretary manages the scenic area to protect its scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and vegetation for wildlife habitat. The area aims to develop old-growth forest characteristics and provide various recreation opportunities. Management purposes take priority over general National Forest System laws and regulations. The Secretary manages the scenic area to protect its scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and vegetation for wildlife habitat, providing a variety of recreation opportunities. In case of conflict, management purposes take precedence over general National Forest System laws and regulations. A management plan must be developed within three years as an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. This does not require a revision of the existing plan. The amendment to the management plan for the Chattahoochee National Forest includes restrictions on new road construction and timber harvest within the scenic area. Vegetation manipulation practices are allowed for wildlife maintenance and public safety. Vegetation management in the scenic area allows for necessary timber harvest for fire, insects, and diseases control, as well as for public safety and trail access. The Secretary may also conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality. Motorized travel is generally prohibited, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires in the scenic area will be suppressed. Within the scenic area, motorized travel may be authorized for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed in a manner consistent with management purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to maintain scenic quality. Water quality will be maintained or enhanced. Federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining, subject to valid existing rights. The scenic area is managed to maintain scenic quality, prevent tree mortality, reduce hazards, and protect private lands. Water quality is maintained or enhanced. Federally owned lands in the area are withdrawn from mining activities. Designation of additional national forest system land as wilderness in Georgia. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, adding to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes additions to Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, and Brasstown Wilderness areas. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, adding to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes additions to Ben Gap, Shoal Branch, Tate Branch, Cedar Mountain, Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch. The Secretary will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for the designated wilderness areas in Georgia, including Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch, for public inspection. The Secretary will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for designated wilderness areas in Georgia, available for public inspection in the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service. The lands designated as wilderness shall be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act and any reference to the effective date of the Wilderness Act shall be deemed to be the date of enactment of this Act. The Federal land designated as wilderness by this section is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws, mining laws, and does not affect the jurisdiction of the State of Georgia with respect to fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral and geothermal leasing or mineral materials.
